newsitem.title: GUATEMALA: Guatemala military police rebel against peace pact.
newsitem.headline: Guatemala military police rebel against peace pact.

text.p: Hundreds of armed Guatemalan military police defied their superiors and seized their own compound on Thursday in the first army rebellion against terms of a peace treaty signed last month.
The protesters demanded severance pay when the 4,000-strong military police (PMA) is dissolved this year as part of promises made by the government in the peace accords signed with leftist rebels.
"For the moment we are staying here. We aren't going to go and we aren't going to turn in our arms," Sgt. Corado told reporters. He refused to give his first name.
It was the first such protest by the country's powerful army since the Dec. 29 peace treaty that ended a 36-year war in which 140,000 Guatemalans died or disappeared.

The fate of the military police was part of a government pledge within that treaty to cut the armed forces by a third. For much of Guatemala's recent history, the army has played a pivotal, and at times brutal, role in political life.

Army spokesman Otto Noack said the peace agreements were clear that all demobilized army personnel would receive government aid for a "productive return" to civilian life, but they did not fix an amount of severance pay.
"That is the big worry of the people who work in the PMA, how much their severance pay or benefits will be," he said.
The protest began late on Wednesday when the military policemen refused to turn in their arms after work and took over their fortified compound in northern Guatemala City.
Most of the urban military policemen work around the city during the day, providing security at banks, government buildings and private businesses.

During the protest some of the police stopped traffic on streets around the compound and harangued drivers. They demanded negotiations with the government, asking for promises of $6,600 to $8,300 severance pay each.
"I am sure that you will not have to leave empty-handed," Gen. Manuel Ventura of the Defence Ministry, who arrived on Thursday at the compound to negotiate with the protesters, told the armed men.
"This is pretty worrying because it is an attempt against the peace treaty," Congressman Gumercindo Donis, president of the Congressional National Defence Committee, told reporters.
